title: Ukiyo-e: WC41
transcript:
Narrator: Curator Janice Katz.

Janice Katz: The golden age of Ukiyo-e, when the Yoshiwara pleasure quarters were thriving, is what
we’re featuring in this room. It also coincides with the careers of famous floating world painters such as
Kitagawa Utamaro, Katsukawa Shunsho, and Chobunsai Eishi. The two works in front of you that you
see, by Kitagawa Utamaro, show two of his rare paintings of beauties. One is a Chinese legendary
figure, Seiobo, or Queen Mother of the West. The other woman that Utamaro has painted is going to the
baths. On the way, she’s encountered two puppies that are playing in front of her and she pauses to look
down at them. So this is a moment in this woman’s daily life, probably a moment that you wouldn’t think
of capturing in a painting, yet it’s a moment that’s very telling of this woman.

Narrator: Practicing woodblock print and installation artist, Yoshida Ayomi.

Yoshida Ayomi: It is fascinating how the artist could have so skillfully captured this moment. It is a kind
of immeasurable beauty. A kind of beauty that people who come to see it remember, and the next day,
when they are involved again in their daily lives, this beauty of the captured moment can still be felt. Its
impression remains inside. I really feel this way about Ukiyo-e, which may appear loud and grandiose,
but the feeling of a captured moment of beauty remains deep inside.

Janice Katz: One of the geniuses of Utamaro is that he’s able to capture these beauties as they go
about their lives in these moments when they think that nobody’s looking at them. And it is really very
touching to see her stopping along her way, pausing to look down at these two puppies.

Yoshida Ayomi: When you look at works like this, it’s the line, a very delicate line that is presented. If a
mistake would have been made you couldn’t redo it. Couldn’t paint over it. From the time you start
painting until the last, you have to keep going. And in this way, it describes the moment of painting
without pause. It is not about expressing one’s strength, but how one stops time and captures an instant
that I can really feel when looking at this work.
